bibl.title: Despatch from Owen L. W. Smith to David J. Hill, December 4, 1901
Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

correspAction.roleName: U.S. Minister Resident and Consul General

p.add: INDEX BUREAU REC'D JAN 13 1902 DEPT OF STATE

div1.p: No. 87. Consular. Consulate General of the United States, Monrovia Liberia, December 4, 1901.
Hon. David J. Hill, Assistant Secretary of State Washington.
Subject. The advisability of reestablishing Consular Agencies along the Coast of Liberia.
Ner. Crosslaud has been requested to investigate and report as to the need of the agencies. Hold.
No. 87, Consular. Consulate General of the United States Monrovia Liberia; December 4, 1901.
Hon. David J. Hill, Assistant Secretary of State, Washington.

Sir: I have the honor to say that Mr. Whitlock, local managing agent for Mssers Yates and Porterfield of 17 and 19 William Street New York City, reached this city last week, and is daily expecting the arrival of a shipment of American merchandises, preparatory to opening up business in this city. Since the announcement that the above American merchants would soon reopen up business in Liberia; many

many men of business and influence in Liberia, have coursed with me relative to the possibility of reestablishing Consular Agencies at Cape Palmas and Grand Bassa, as well as establishing one, each, at Greenville (Sinoe County) and at Robertsport (Grand Cape Mount Territory), in order to facilitate the shipment of African products, in exchange for American products and manufactures. I call your attention to the foregoing, in order, that you may take the matter under advisement &c.
I have the honor to be your obedient servant; Owen L. W. Smith, Consul General.
